historical drama directed by ava duvenay
and released in december of 2014. it's a
gripping portrait of america during the
1960s when discrimination was rampant
and black people struggled for their
right to vote despite violent opposition
dr martin luther king jr led his
followers on an epic march from selma to
montgomery which culminated in president
lyndon johnson signing the voting rights
act of 1965. king is portrayed by david
arjello a performance that earned him
critical praise in his first golden
globe nomination dubane and or yellow
had worked together back in 2012 on the

the important thing is that duvernay got
her hands on the project and according
to her own estimations rewrote about 90
of webb's script she spent hours
listening to king's words and speeches
studying his vocal patterns his basic
sentence structures and nuances of his
phrasing and it's this attention to
detail that sets duvenay apart from
other writer directors however a
stipulation in webb's original contract
entitled him to sole credit on the
script so duvenay wasn't credited as a
screenwriter despite her notable efforts
but that didn't stop her from receiving
an outpouring of praise especially her
direction the washington post wrote that
director ava duvenay has created a

the farewell is a 2019 dramedy written
and directed by lulu wang it's the story
of a chinese-american writer named billy
wang who received word that her beloved
grandmother ninai has been diagnosed
with terminal lung cancer and only has a
few months to live bilia returns to
china under the guise of a fake wedding
to go bertley say goodbye to ninai why
covertly well because grandma ninai is
the only person in the family that
doesn't know she's dying the film stars
aquafina sema
dinan lin and xiao susan and was
distributed by a24 the company behind
the acclaimed films ex machina room
moonlight and the wildly popular tv
series euphoria
la la
wang's inspiration for the farewell came
from her own life experience which she
shared on an episode of this american
life in 2016.
in the episode wang discussed an
elaborate ruse that her extended family
orchestrated in order to bid farewell to
her dying grandmother much like the film
the family wanted the opportunity to say
goodbye to their matriarch without her
knowing about her own three-month life
expectancy i could see how some might
think that this is a pretty cruel tactic
but as wang's fictionalized mother in
the film poignantly explains the chinese
maxim is people don't die of cancer they
die of the fear so i guess the jury is
still out on whether this was a cruel
approach or not but one thing that's not
up for debate is that the farewell is a
heartfelt film with thematic depth and
well-placed humor and above all is a
testament to wang's brilliance as a
director
